title.narrative: QUALITY AND INCLUSIVE CHILD PROTECTION AND JUSTICE SERVICES

description.narrative: Output 3.2: Social service workforce and the justice sector have increased capacity to provide quality and inclusive child protection and justice services, which contributes to Access To Justice, Adolescent Empowerment, Evaluation And Research, Harmful Practices (Fgm/C And Child Marriage), Prevention And Response Services For Violence Against Children, Prevention And Response Services For Violence Against Children (Covid). UNICEF aims to achieve this through Advocacy And Public Engagement, Developing And Leveraging Resources And Partnerships, Evaluations, Research And Data, Fostering Innovation And Use Of New Technologies, Operational Support To Programme Delivery, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building, United Nations Working Together. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: Outcome 301: By 2023, children and adolescents, especially the most vulnerable, will increasingly benefit from quality, inclusive and gender- responsive child protection system

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: Output 3.2: Social service workforce and the justice sector have increased capacity to provide quality and inclusive child protection and justice services

description.narrative: Towards strengthening social service workforce to prevent and respond to violence against children, 349 (128 female) women and children committee members and front liners in 10 districts and 4 municipalities have enhanced skills to deal with survivors of GBV and identify and safely refer child protection issues for appropriate services. With school closure due to COVID-19 and children accessing education online, 1533 adolescents and youth (977 female) were equipped with the skills and knowledge to stay safe online. 684 children (258 girls) and 327 adults (120 female) out of 20,0000 have also been provided with remote counselling and psychosocial support. | Status:On-track | As-of Date:28/08/2020
